Indeed, he would recite in the dawn prayer of Friday the Chapter of the Prostration [as-Sajdah], Luqman, and the Chapter "Has there come upon man..." [al-Insan]. And know that among his [Satan's] stratagems [makayid] is to preoccupy you in your prayer with remembrance of the Hereafter [al-Akhirah] and planning good deeds, to prevent you from understanding what you recite. So know that everything which distracts you from understanding the meanings of your recitation is a whispering [waswas]. For the movement of the tongue is not the intended goal; rather, the intended goal is its meanings. As for recitation, people concerning it are of three kinds: a man whose tongue moves while his heart [qalb] is heedless; and a man whose tongue moves and his heart follows the tongue, so he understands and hears from it as if he were hearing it from anotherâ€”and these are the degrees of the Companions of the Right Hand; and a man whose heart [qalb] precedes to the meanings first, then the tongue serves the heart by translating it. So distinguish between the tongue being an interpreter for the heart [qalb] or being a teacher for the heart [qalb]. And those brought near [al-muqarrabun], their tongue is an interpreter that follows the heart [qalb], and the heart [qalb] does not follow it. And likewise, you must understand what you recite from the chapters, as will come in the Book of the Recitation of the Quran. So do not be heedless of its command and its prohibition, its promise and its threat, its admonitions, the stories of its prophets, the mention of His favors and His benevolence. And for each one there is a right: hope [ar-raja'] is the right of the promise, and fear [al-khawf] is the right of the threat.

They argued with His saying, the Exalted: 'And among the people is he who purchases idle talk (lahw al-hadith) to mislead from the path of Allah without knowledge and takes it in ridicule; those will have a humiliating punishment.' Ibn Mas'ud, Al-Hasan Al-Basri, and Al-Nakha'i, may Allah be pleased with them, said that idle talk (lahw al-hadith) is singing (ghina'). And 'A'isha, may Allah be pleased with her, narrated that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Indeed, Allah, the Exalted, has forbidden the singing-girl (al-qayna) and her sale, her price, and her teaching.' The hadith of 'A'isha: 'Indeed, Allah has forbidden the singing-girl (al-qayna) and her sale, her price, and her teaching' was reported by Al-Tabarani in Al-Awsat with a weak chain; Al-Bayhaqi said it is not preserved. So we say: As for the singing-girl (al-qayna), what is intended by it is the female slave who sings for men in a drinking gathering, and we have mentioned that the singing of a non-mahram woman for corrupt people and those whom one fears temptation (fitna) for is forbidden, and they do not intend by temptation (fitna) except what is prohibited. As for the singing of the female slave for her owner, its prohibition is not understood from this hadith; rather, for other than her owner, listening to her in the absence of temptation (fitna) is evidenced by what is narrated in the two Sahihs from the singing of the two female slaves in the house of 'A'isha, may Allah be pleased with her. And as for purchasing idle talk (lahw al-hadith) with religion, exchanging it to mislead by it from the path of Allah, it is forbidden and blameworthy, and there is no dispute in it. And not every singing is an exchange for religion, purchased with it, and misleading from the path of Allah, the Exalted, and that is what is intended in the verse. And if one recited the Quran to mislead by it from the path of Allah, it would be forbidden; it is narrated about some hypocrites that he used to lead the people in prayer and would not recite except Surah 'Abasa because of what is in it of reproach with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, so 'Umar intended to kill him.

a.g: And when our verses are recited to him, he turns away arrogantly as if he had not heard them, as if there was in his ears deafness. So give him tidings of a painful punishment.
Indeed, those who believe and do righteous deeds - for them are the Gardens of Pleasure.
Wherein they abide eternally; [it is] the promise of Allah [which is] truth. And He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise.

He created the heavens without pillars that you see and has cast into the earth firmly set mountains, lest it should shift with you, and dispersed therein from every creature. And We sent down rain from the sky and made grow therein [plants] of every noble kind.
This is the creation of Allah. So show Me what those other than Him have created. Rather, the wrongdoers are in clear error.

And We had certainly given Luqman wisdom [and said], "Be grateful to Allah." And whoever is grateful is grateful for [the benefit of] himself. And whoever denies [His favor] - then indeed, Allah is Free of need and Praiseworthy.
And [mention, O Muhammad], when Luqman said to his son while he was instructing him, "O my son, do not associate [anything] with Allah. Indeed, association [with him] is great injustice."

And We have enjoined upon man [care] for his parents. His mother carried him, [increasing her] in weakness upon weakness, and his weaning is in two years. Be grateful to Me and to your parents; to Me is the [final] destination.

But if they endeavor to make you associate with Me that of which you have no knowledge, do not obey them but accompany them in [this] world with appropriate kindness and follow the way of those who turn back to Me [in repentance]. Then to Me will be your return, and I will inform you about what you used to do.

And because observing immorality (Fisq) and immoral people (Fussaq) makes sin seem trivial to the Heart (Qalb) and nullifies the Heart's (Qalb) aversion from it. Said Sa'id ibn al-Musayyib: 'Do not look at the wrongdoers lest your righteous deeds be invalidated.' Rather, these peopleâ€”there is no safety in associating with them, and safety is only in cutting off from them. Said Allah the Exalted: 'And when the ignorant address them, they say: Peace (Salam)' meaning safety, and the Alif is substituted for the Ha, and its meaning is: 'We are safe from your sin, and you are safe from our harm.' This is what we intended to mention of the meanings of brotherhood, its conditions, and its benefits. So let us return to mentioning its rights, necessities, and ways of fulfilling its right. As for the one greedy for the worldly life (Dunya), his companionship is deadly poison because natures are predisposed to imitation and emulation; indeed, nature steals from nature without its owner realizing. Sitting with the greedy for the worldly life (Dunya) stirs greed, and sitting with the ascetic (Zahid) makes one ascetic toward the worldly life (Dunya). Therefore, the companionship of seekers of the worldly life (Dunya) is disliked, and the companionship of those desirous of the Hereafter (Akhira) is recommended. Said Ali (upon him be peace): 'Revive acts of obedience by sitting with one from whom you feel shame.' And said Ahmad ibn Hanbal (may Allah have mercy on him): 'Nothing has landed me in tribulation except the companionship of one I do not respect.' All of this is the character traits of arrogance and its effects that result from pride in knowledge and action. Where is the one who is free from all of that or from some of it? And whoever knows it, it is incumbent upon him not to be arrogant and not to see for himself a status. This is arrogance through knowledge and action.

Therefore, from the etiquettes of enjoining good and forbidding evil (al-Hisbah) is preparing the Soul (Nafs) for patience (al-Sabr). And for this reason, Allah the Exalted coupled patience with commanding good, saying, narrating from Luqman: 'O my son, establish the prayer (al-Salah) and command good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbid evil (al-Munkar) and be patient (wa-isbir) over what befalls you.' And what pertains to the Lord (Al-Rabb) the Exalted is either a contemplation (Nadhar) in His Essence (Dhat) and His Attributes (Sifat) and His Beautiful Names (Asma' al-Husna), or it is in His Actions (Af'al) and His Dominion (Mulk) and His Sovereignty (Malakut) and all that is in the heavens and the earth and what is between them. And it becomes clear to you the confinement of thought (Fikr) in these divisions by an example, which is that the state (Hal) of those who journey (Al-Sa'irin) to Allah the Exalted and those who yearn (Al-Mushtaqin) for meeting Him pertains to His Beloved (Ma'shuq) or pertains to himself. So if he contemplates in his Beloved, then either he contemplates in His Beauty (Jamal) and the goodness of His Form (Surah) in His Essence (Dhat) to delight in the thought (Fikr) in Him and in witnessing Him (Mushahadah), or he contemplates in His Gentle (Latif), Good (Hasan) Actions (Af'al) that indicate His Morals (Akhlaq) and Attributes (Sifat) so that this becomes a multiplier of pleasure (Ladhdhah) and a strengthener of his love (Mahabbah). And if he contemplates in himself, then his thought (Fikr) is in his attributes (Sifat) that drop him from the eye of his Beloved (Ma'shuq) until he becomes purified (Yatanazzah) from them, or in the attributes (Sifat) that bring him near to Him and make him beloved to Him until he becomes characterized (Yattasif) by them. So if he contemplates in something outside of these divisions, then that is outside the limit of passionate love (Al-'Ishq) and it is a deficiency in it, because the complete (Al-Kamil), perfect (Al-Tamm) passionate love (Al-'Ishq) is what overwhelms the lover (Al-'Ashiq) and fills the Heart (Al-Qalb) until it does not leave in it room for other than Him. So the lover (Muhibb) of Allah the Exalted ought to be like that, so his gaze (Nadhar) and thought (Fikr) do not exceed his Beloved (Ma'shuq). And as long as his thought (Fikr) is confined in these four divisions, it is not outside the requirement of love (Mahabbah) at all. So let us begin with the first division, which is his contemplation (Tafakkur) in the attributes (Sifat) of himself and the actions (Af'al) of himself to distinguish the beloved (Al-Mahbub) among them from the disliked (Al-Makruh), for this thought (Fikr) is what pertains to the knowledge of transaction (Ilm al-Mu'amalah) which is the intended purpose of this book. So measure the Hereafter (Al-Akhirah) by the first, for 'Your creation and your resurrection are not but like a single Soul (Nafs)' and the second creation (Nash'ah) is only according to the measure of the first creation (Nash'ah). Rather, the numbers of creations (Nash'at) are not limited to two, and to this is the indication by His saying, the Exalted: 'And We will create you in what you do not know.' So the one who affirms the two resurrections (Qiyamatayn) is a believer in the world of the unseen (Al-Ghayb) and the witnessed (Al-Shahadah), and certain of the dominion (Al-Mulk) and the sovereignty (Al-Malakut). And the one who affirms the minor resurrection (Al-Qiyamah Al-Sughra) without the major (Al-Kubra) is looking with the one-eyed eye (Al-'Ayn Al-'Awra') to one of the two worlds, and that is ignorance (Al-Jahl) and misguidance (Al-Dalal) and following the one-eyed Dajjal. So how great is your heedlessness (Ghaflah), O wretched one, and all of us are that wretched one, and before you are these terrors. If you do not believe in the major resurrection (Al-Qiyamah Al-Kubra) due to ignorance (Al-Jahl) and misguidance (Al-Dalal), does not the indication of the minor resurrection (Al-Qiyamah Al-Sughra) suffice you? Or have you not heard the saying of the master of the prophets: 'Sufficient is death as a warner' or have you not heard Abu Bakr, upon him be peace, at death until he said: 'O Allah, make easy for Muhammad the agonies of death'? Or are you not ashamed of your delay in the assault of death, following the riffraff of the heedless (Al-Ghafilun) who do not look except at a single blast that seizes them while they are disputing, so they cannot make a will nor return to their families? This is in this world (Dunya), so how about on a day when a parent (Walid) will not avail his child (Walad) at all, nor will a child (Mawlud) avail his parent (Walid) anything? Rather, the Prophets (Anbiya') will say in it: 'Myself, myself!' So how does the ignorant one exchange the reward of the Hereafter (Akhirah) and attaining closeness (Qurb) with Allah (God) for what he anticipates with his false greed in this world (Dunya) from people? Thus, we should not doubt that the show-off (Mura'i) with obedience (Taa'ah) to Allah (God) is in the displeasure (Sakhat) of Allah (God) from both transmission (Naql) and analogy (Qiyas) togetherâ€”this is if he did not intend the reward (Ajr); but if he intended the reward (Ajr) and praise (Hamd) together in his charity (Sadaqah) or prayer (Salah), then it is the association (Shirk) that contradicts sincerity (Ikhlas).
